Pero era la suya una alegría casi histérica, que le oprimía el ánimo.
==========

La sensación de vivir, la conciencia de sí mismo, casi se decuplicaban en aquellos instantes fugaces como el relámpago
==========
﻿El Idiota (Spanish Edition) (Dostoievski, Fiódor)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 4081-4083 | Añadido el jueves, 2 de mayo de 2024 08:22:54

En medio del abatimiento, melancolía, oscuridad y opresión de ánimo que experimentaba el enfermo en tales ocasiones, parecía, a trechos, surgir en su cerebro un rayo de luz y dijérase que todas sus energías vitales se esforzaban de pronto, trabajando al máximo de intensidad.
==========
﻿El Idiota (Spanish Edition) (Dostoievski, Fiódor)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 4083-4086 | Añadido el jueves, 2 de mayo de 2024 08:23:09

La sensación de vivir, la conciencia de sí mismo, casi se decuplicaban en aquellos instantes fugaces como el relámpago. Una claridad extraordinaria iluminaba su espíritu y su corazón. Todas las agitaciones se calmaban, todas las dudas y perplejidades se resolvían a la vez en una armonía suprema, en una tranquilidad serena y alegre, plenamente racional y justificada.
==========
﻿El Idiota (Spanish Edition) (Dostoievski, Fiódor)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 4099-4099 | Añadido el jueves, 2 de mayo de 2024 08:24:28

==========

«¿Y qué, si esto es enfermedad? ¿Qué importa que se trate de una tensión anormal si su resultado, tal como lo considero y analizo cuando vuelvo a mi estado corriente, contiene armonía y belleza en el máximo grado, y si en ese minuto experimento una sensación inaudita
==========
﻿El Idiota (Spanish Edition) (Dostoievski, Fiódor)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 4090-4093 | Añadido el jueves, 2 de mayo de 2024 08:24:47

«¿Y qué, si esto es enfermedad? ¿Qué importa que se trate de una tensión anormal si su resultado, tal como lo considero y analizo cuando vuelvo a mi estado corriente, contiene armonía y belleza en el máximo grado, y si en ese minuto experimento una sensación inaudita, insospechada hasta entonces, de plenitud, de ritmo, de paz, de éxtasis devoto que me inmerge en la más alta síntesis de la vida?»
==========

Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 147 | posición 2075-2076 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:16:32

After removing immediate threats to the child’s safety (when possible) and ensuring they are not harming themselves, the adults in the child’s life increase their sense of safety especially by their predictable actions and presence
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 149 | posición 2102-2104 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:16:54

Just like therapy for adults, it is important not to do “exposure” therapy (talking about details of traumatic memories) with a child if they are not in a safe situation and/or if they dissociate when discussing the memories.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 150 | posición 2107-2109 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:17:24

Developmentally appropriate modifications of coping skills taught to adults can be used with children, including forms of deep breathing, tightening muscles and relaxing them, mindfulness strategies, changing self-talk and thoughts, and activities that help calm or soothe them. For
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 150 | posición 2109-2110 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:17:41

reducing dissociation is achieved especially by addressing safety concerns and involving safe, predictable adults in their lives, as well as teaching basic emotion identification and coping skills.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 150 | posición 2113-2114 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:19:15

Teaching safety skills to a child or adolescent, such as that their body is their own, establishing boundaries (e.g., their “bubble” for younger children and space between themselves and others for older children), and the concepts of respect for their body and others’ bodies is essential.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 2126-2128 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:21:21

The type of attachment that she had developed with the therapist helped her to feel safe enough to show emotions at all and to be able to recover and return to the present. This is part of how recovery can occur for a child. The
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 2126-2129 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:21:30

The type of attachment that she had developed with the therapist helped her to feel safe enough to show emotions at all and to be able to recover and return to the present. This is part of how recovery can occur for a child. The therapist, in addition to other caring, safe adults, provides the child with more secure, predictable attachments to gradually alter the child’s internal template
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 151 | posición 2126-2129 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:21:34

The type of attachment that she had developed with the therapist helped her to feel safe enough to show emotions at all and to be able to recover and return to the present. This is part of how recovery can occur for a child. The therapist, in addition to other caring, safe adults, provides the child with more secure, predictable attachments to gradually alter the child’s internal template of themselves and of themselves with others.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)

==========

- La subrayado en la página 154 | posición 2157-2159 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:26:49

One therapy method for enhancing the caregiver–child relationship is through the child-directed interaction phase of parent–child interaction therapy or PCIT [2
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2166-2167 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:29:27

When a child appears to be dissociating, reassurance by the presence of a trusted other, such as in the example of Nathan with his adoptive parents, is a preferred way to help a child reduce dissociation and return to the present.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2167-2168 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:29:44

Returning the discussion to what or who keeps them safe or changing to less emotionally provoking topics also can facilitate reorientation to the present.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2169-2169 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:29:56

physical movement can also help to reorient a child.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2169-2171 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:30:08

When recalling past traumatic events, having the child sit on an exercise ball or other balancing object helps prevent the body from freezing and prompts the child to maintain some focus on the present in order to
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2169-2171 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:30:12

When recalling past traumatic events, having the child sit on an exercise ball or other balancing object helps prevent the body from freezing and prompts the child to maintain some focus on the present in order to keep their balance.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 155 | posición 2176-2177 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:30:55

In reality, both children and memories don’t always go with our preferred timing on things. Children often reveal bits and pieces of their past during the course of everyday life.
==========

==========

==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 156 | posición 2183-2184 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:31:52

For many reasons, children may display their traumas and their feelings about them instead of saying them.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 156 | posición 2185-2186 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:32:07

The developmental level at which the traumatic event occurred affects how the child understands and responds to what happened and to what extent they can retell it.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 157 | posición 2195-2196 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:33:04

In addition to a lack of words for traumatic memories, the memories also may be in fragments that didn’t make sense to the child at the time or in the present.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 157 | posición 2195-2199 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:33:13

In addition to a lack of words for traumatic memories, the memories also may be in fragments that didn’t make sense to the child at the time or in the present. One goal, once the child is ready, is to put the pieces back together in an order that makes more sense, clarify it wasn’t their fault, change associations with trauma reminders, and help make sense of the feelings that went with the experience. Then, the memory can be stored in the past properly or, as one child announced, “All of it is in the front of my brain and I want it to go into the back of my brain.”
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 159 | posición 2219-2220 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:35:15

She put visual memories down on paper, was assisted in finding words for what happened and her feelings about it, created new associations with a previous trauma reminder (being in her own room), and received ongoing reassurances of her safety from her grandparents
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 160 | posición 2227-2228 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:36:43

It can be extremely stressful for a caregiver to care for a child who has been traumatized and shows trauma responses, including dissociation.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 160 | posición 2230-2231 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:37:05

The child’s responses may even serve to activate trauma responses or intensify feelings of guilt by the caregiver, whether valid or exaggerated, about the caregiver’s inability to prevent the harm to the child and the residual effects.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 160 | posición 2232-2233 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:37:24

This can be exhausting and often results in yet another situation where the caregiver minimizes or avoids their own responses in order to care for someone else.
==========
Disconnecting to Survive: Understanding and Recovering from Trauma-based Dissociation - Pamela Fuller (Pamela Fuller)
- La subrayado en la página 160 | posición 2234-2235 | Añadido el sábado, 4 de mayo de 2024 23:38:13

the child benefits from the caregiver doing better emotionally and is negatively affected if the caregiver is struggling emotionally and/or is not fully present.
==========

Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 62 | posición 784-787 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 08:46:56

You have to keep a dozen of your favorite problems constantly present in your mind, although by and large they will lay in a dormant state. Every time you hear or read a new trick or a new result, test it against each of your twelve problems to see whether it helps. Every once in a while there will be a hit, and people will say, “How did he do it? He must be a genius!”
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 62 | posición 787-788 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 08:47:20

Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 64 | posición 816-818 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 08:55:10

Notice that some of these questions are abstract, while others are concrete. Some express deep longings, while others are more like spontaneous interests. Many are questions about how to live a better life, while a few are focused on how to succeed professionally. The key to this exercise is to make them open-ended questions that don’t necessarily have a single answer.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 64 | posición 819-821 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 08:56:01

The power of your favorite problems is that they tend to stay fairly consistent over time. The exact framing of each question may change, but even as we move between projects, jobs, relationships, and careers, our favorite problems tend to follow us across the years.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 65 | posición 829-830 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 08:57:21

The goal isn’t to definitively answer the question once and for all, but to use the question as a North Star for my learning.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 66 | posición 844-847 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:01:22

The problem is, it’s an in-depth how-to article that is thousands of words long. Even if you spend the twenty or thirty minutes it would take to consume it now, in the future you’ll just have to spend all that time reading it again, since you’ll have forgotten most of the details. You also don’t want to just bookmark the link and save it to read later, because then you won’t know what it contains in the first place!
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 67 | posición 851-852 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:01:55

You can extract only the most salient, relevant, rich material and save it as a succinct note.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 67 | posición 852-853 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:02:02

Don’t save entire chapters of a book—save only select passages. Don’t save complete transcripts of interviews—save a few of the best quotes.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 67 | posición 855-857 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:02:23

- La subrayado en la página 68 | posición 865-867 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:04:23

==========

- La subrayado en la página 69 | posición 885-886 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:11:00

==========

- La subrayado en la página 70 | posición 902-904 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:14:32

When you use up too much energy taking notes, you have little left over for the subsequent steps that add far more value: making connections, imagining possibilities, formulating theories, and creating new ideas of your own.

==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 76 | posición 978-978 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:26:43

First, you are much more likely to remember information you’ve written down in your own words.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 76 | posición 978-980 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:27:01

First, you are much more likely to remember information you’ve written down in your own words. Known as the “Generation Effect,”10 researchers have found that when people actively generate a series of words, such as by speaking or writing, more parts of their brain are activated when compared to simply reading the same words.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 77 | posición 985-986 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 09:27:28

Perhaps the most immediate benefit of capturing content outside our heads is that we escape what I call the “reactivity loop”—the hamster wheel of urgency, outrage, and sensationalism that characterizes so much of the Internet.

Here’s the problem: the moment you first capture an idea is the worst time to try to decide what it relates to. First, because you’ve just encountered it and haven’t had any time to ponder its ultimate purpose, but more importantly,
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 101 | posición 1271-1274 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 10:25:11

Here’s the problem: the moment you first capture an idea is the worst time to try to decide what it relates to. First, because you’ve just encountered it and haven’t had any time to ponder its ultimate purpose, but more importantly, because forcing yourself to make decisions every time you capture something adds a lot of friction to the process.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 102 | posición 1275-1276 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 10:25:24

This is why it’s so important to separate capture and organize into two distinct steps: “keeping what resonates” in the moment is a separate decision from deciding to save something for the long term.
==========

- La subrayado en la página 102 | posición 1286-1288 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 10:26:30

- La subrayado en la página 118 | posición 1483-1484 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:44:07

- La subrayado en la página 118 | posición 1486-1487 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:44:38

==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 118 | posición 1487-1489 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:44:46

Discoverability is an idea from information science that refers to “the degree to which a piece of content or information can be found in a search of a file, database, or other information system.”
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 118 | posición 1493-1494 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:45:44

To enhance the discoverability of your notes, we can turn to a simple habit you probably remember from school: highlighting the most important points.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 119 | posición 1499-1501 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:46:41

This points to a paradox that a lot of people experience as they take notes: the more notes they gather, the more the volume of information grows, the more time and effort it takes to review it all, and the less time they have to do so.
==========
Building a Second Brain A Proven Method to Organize Your Digital Life and Unlock Your Creative Potential  (Tiago Forte)
- La subrayado en la página 120 | posición 1516-1517 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 15:48:19

The technique is simple: you highlight the main points of a note, and then highlight the main points of those highlights, and so on, distilling the essence of a note in several “layers.”
==========

#3: Making Highlighting Difficult

- La subrayado en la página 140 | posición 1708-1710 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 16:13:07

- La subrayado en la página 141 | posición 1720-1721 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 16:13:58

==========

- La subrayado en la página 152 | posición 1871-1872 | Añadido el viernes, 10 de mayo de 2024 16:26:30

I call “Intermediate Packets.” Intermediate Packets are the concrete, individual building blocks that make up your work.
==========
